loans.name: Eom

texts.en: Eom N., 59, is married and resides in Battambong Province with his wife (pictured) and a child. To make a living, He manufactures rice wine and raises pigs for their offspring at home, earning an income of US $3 per day. His wife travels through the town and villages in the province to collect and purchase recyclable materials for resale, earning an income of US $3 per day to cover the family expenses. This couple is seeking to improve their standard of living by working hard every day. Therefore, N. is asking for a loan of US $1000 to purchase a motorbike to transport the rice wine product and recycle materials to sell. By doing so, N. hopes that she will be able to cut back on public transportation expenses and save the extra income for the future household use.

loans.use: buy a motorbike to transport wine for sale

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita is involved in a hog-raising business and it has been her main source of income since she got married. She is requesting a loan of PHP 4,000 to be used in purchasing feed for her grown-up pigs and to purchase additional piglets to raise. She would like to improve and grow her hog-raising business and hopefully she will be able to obtain the loan she has requested. 

Nenita is a 40-year-old businesswoman who lives with her husband and two children in the village of Santa Isabel Norte, Ilagan, Isabela. She sends her two children to school and, hopefully, her eldest child, who is now in college, will finish her studies and earn a degree. Her youngest is still in primary school and Nenita also aims to provide the education she needs to be able to acquire better opportunities in life someday.

Nenita hopes that her husband will always be patient in working on their farm so that they will be able to help each other in attaining their aspirations.

loans.use: To buy piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Juditha

texts.en:
Juditha G. is from the town of Kinangay Sur Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 66 years old. Juditha is widowed and has five grown children. To make a living, Juditha owns and operates a business raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Juditha has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $215 a month from these activities.

In 2003, Juditha joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juditha has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from GDMPC. Juditha is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This will be her sixth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Nipasin

texts.en:
Nipasin E. is currently in the business of baking and selling bread and is requesting a loan to purchase more baking flour.

Nipasin is 45 years old and is married to a husband who is a builder. She has 5 children and four of her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rental purposes.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase more baking flour

loans.name: Peou

texts.en: S. is a 50-year-old farmer who lives in Kampong Chhnang province. S. is a widowed mother blessed with six children: three are married and have ready started new homes, two are students, one works on the farm. S. currently owns a cultivating machine that she uses for her farming. In addition, she uses her machine to plow a nearby farmer’s farmland for profit. Unfortunately, the machine has often broken down during the plowing process. Because of this problem, S. would like a loan to purchase spare parts in order to replace a part of the cultivating machine. Note: S. was not available for photographing, so her son is shown instead.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts in order to replace a part of the cultivating machine

loans.name: Yorng

texts.en: Yorng V., 37, is married with 2 school-aged children. He resides in Battambong Province with his wife and children. To make a living, he produces quality rice wine and uses wastes from his manufacturing as food for raising pigs. He is able to earn an income of US $3 per day in revenue. His wife is helps him in the business to double his work and earns the same amount of income to him. This couple tries to work hard every day to ensure that their standard of living is improved. Therefore, V. is asking for a loan of US $500 to purchase animal food added to the current animal he has so that his pigs are able to grow up efficiently to reach maximum prices at the market. By doing so, he hopes he will generate extra income for his family to save for the future household use.

loans.use: buy pig food

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena R. is 38 years of age, she manages a retail store in their village for almost six years,her weekly net income is PHP 1,500.00, she requested a loan amount of PHP 10,000.00 to purchase some grocery items to sell. She works hard for her family to support her family in their daily needs.

She is married to Reynaldo R., a barangay Captain in their village. They have one son named Reynald- 17 years of age, 2nd year college student. They are three family members residing together at San Francisco Cauayan City, a rural and plain area, 15 kilometers away from the city proper of Cauayan. She is optimistic when it comes to business. She said that we should anticipate a positive outcome in handling a small business.

loans.use: Additional capital to purchase some grocery items to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase  more rice, beans, maize flour and sugar in bulk

loans.name: Ofelia

texts.en:
Ofelia is managing a village store for ten years.  She aspires to make her business grow and become more profitable for the welfare of her three children who are all studying. Ofelia is requesting to avail a loan amounting to PHP25,000 that she will use as business capital and for the expansion of her business.  She hopes that the KIVA lenders will help her to further improve her business by purchasing more stocks of grocery items.

Ofelia is 36 years old and married to Wilfredo who works as a farmer in their village. She and her husband are doing their best to improve their way of living.

loans.use: Additional revolving capital for the expansion of her retailing business

loans.name: Rida

texts.en:
Mrs. Rida S., age 25 and her husband, Mr. Phally Bun, age 32, live on an island on the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They were married since 2003 and have 3 children-2 sons and daughter. All of them are still young.   

Rida has been selling finished silk fabric since 2008. She buys it from weavers in her village and transports for resale at other provinces, far a way from her house. Besides of the business, she also designs pattern for fabric. Her husband has full-time employment in Phnom Penh in 2003.

Rida is requesting a loan of $700 in order to purchase more finished silk fabric for resale. It will able be better for her to manage income for supporting the family.

loans.use: To purchase more finished silk fabric for resale.

loans.name: Getruda

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 27  years old Getruda  M.  from Mbarali  She is married  with one   child, of 5 yrs old  Getruda has been running a clothes  business since 2006. Client’s business is purchasing and selling clothes. She works at the business for 9-12  hours per day, 6 days per week Getruda currently earns about 200 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase clothes in bulk for her business . In the future, she plans to open the same business at new location . Getruda thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase clothes in bulk for her business

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace O. is from the village of Tabo-o, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 38 years old. Grace is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Grace owns and operates a business in the retail sector, buying and selling fish in the local community. Grace has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately $50 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Grace joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Grace has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. Grace is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This will be her fourth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac F. is currently in the business of selling green vegetables and beans and is requesting a loan to purchase hens and cocks to sell.

Isaac is 48 years old and is married to a husband who is a policeman. She has 2 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase hens and cocks to sell

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is 46 years of age and she is married to Jovencio S., they are blessed with three children, they are Josielyn- 30 years of age, followed by her sister Flordeliza- 23 years of age, and their youngest is Fely Jean- 19 years of age, they are all married. They are peacefully living together at San Francisco, Alicia Isabela, a rural area. Their house is located near their barangay basketball court.
She manages a retail store in their village for almost ten years, her weekly net income is PHP 500.00,she plans to avail a loan amount of PHP 3,000.00 to purchase some grocery items to sell in her retail store,being a grandmother to her grandchildren is very hard for her, because she's the one who always supports their daily needs, she hopes that KIVA lenders will grant her the loan as much as possible.

loans.use: Additional Capital to purchase grocery items for her store

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida is engaged in vegetable vending in their village.  She sells her products by roaming around their village and going from one house to another.  Having vegetables in their backyard helps her save more income. She hopes to maintain her business for it serves as their main source of income.  

Aida is requesting for a loan amounting to PHP8,000. This amount will be of great help to further expand her business.  She hopes that the lenders will support her business for her to achieve her dreams.  Through her business, she is also positive that their way of living will also improve and develop.  

Aida is 42 years old and lives in the village of Minallo, Naguilian, Isabela.  She is married to Wilfredo, 61 years old and works as a farmer.  They have four children and she is happy that they are all working.  She hopes that they will all be successful in life someday.

loans.use: Additional capital to maintain her retail business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase  more sugar, rice, onions,and beans in bulk for reselling

loans.name: Thoang

texts.en:
Thoang S., 22, is married with a two-year-old child. She resides with her husband (pictured) in Battambong Province, Cambodia. To make a living, she raises ducks at home, earning approximately an income of US $1.50 per day. Her husband is a construction builder who has to travel from place to place in the province, earning an income of US $5 per day.

This young couple is seeking ways to improve their standard of living and to save more money for future household use. Therefore, S. is asking for a loan of US $600 to purchase a motorbike to commute to work. By doing so, S. hopes that she will be able to cut back on public transportation expense and save extra income.

loans.use: buy a motorbike

loans.name: 02-Ái Sơn 2 Group

texts.pt:
"Phương N. Thị (28) is a 46 year-old female living in the town of Thanh Hoá.  Phương is the group leader of a 4-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 02-Ái Sơn 2 (16-03-02).


Phương is married and has 2 adult -aged children.  To making a living, Phương operates a family member's business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting rice for sale.  Phương has been engaged in this business for over 15 years and earns approximately 2000000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2004, Phương joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Phương has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3079800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise.  She is now requesting a new loan of 6000000 VND which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise.  The loan will be the 20th loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Phương plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  Lê Thị Hương (38) is a 26 year-old female who is requesting a 6000000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store.


2.  N. Thị Gai (37) is a 60 year-old female who is requesting a 6000000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising crops.


3.  Ngô Thị Xuân (23) is a 49 year-old female who is requesting a 6000000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising crops.


About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Phương N. Thị (28) là 46 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoá.  Phương là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 4 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 02-Ái Sơn 2 (16-03-02).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ trồng & thu hoạch gạo để bán.  Phương thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 15 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Phương kiếm được khoảng 2000000 VND.  Vào 2004, Phương đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Phương đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3,079,800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua hạt giống bổ sung, cây giống & cây con để trồng.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6,000,000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 20th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Lê Thị Hương (38) là 26 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng.


2.  N. Thị Gai (37) là 60 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là trồng cây lương thực.


3.  Ngô Thị Xuân (23) là 49 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là trồng cây lương thực.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 39 years old Stella Mbazuha from Mbarali. She is married  with 4 children, between the ages of 3  and 12. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting 2  dependants because orphans . Stella has been running a genge business since 2007. Client’s business is A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood, with a tin roof, which sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chilli, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal, and don’t have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.
. She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by one  employee. Stella currently earns about 200 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase  genge items in bulk for business. In the future, she plans to open the same business at new location . Stella thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase  genge items in bulk

loans.name: Heang

texts.en: C., 27, is hard work woman who tries to earn money from a suitable job. In the past, she planted a rice crop but she right now works as a seamstress for a garment industry. She gets a specific salary of $90 a month to be managed all her family’s living requirements. She is married with three young children, while her husband works on the farm (he is shown in the picture above). C. is hardly commuting to work because she doesn’t have her own vehicle for traveling purposes. Because of this obstacle, she decided to ask a loan to add to her little saving in order to buy a used motor to ride to work.

loans.use: To buy a used motor to ride to work

loans.name: Chhun

texts.en:
Chhun M., 36, is married with two school-aged children. She resides in Battambong Province, Cambodia with her husband (pictured) and children. To make a living, she is engaged in a business of selling grilled beef and boiled duck eggs by commuting everywhere in the town, earning an income of US $5 per day in revenue. Her husband operates his motor taxi in the town and local markets, earning an income of US $2.50 per day.

This couple tries to work hard every day to ensure good living for their children and family. M. is seeking to improve her business, so she is asking for a loan of US$ 1000 to purchase a trailer and various kinds of meatballs to expand her business. By doing so, she hopes she will be able to generate more income to keep investing in her business and save the more money for future household use.

loans.use: buy a trailer and various kinds of meatballs

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
“ If you are responsible, you will achieve your goal.”  An inspiring quotation shared by Mrs. Evangeline P. one of the responsible mothers in bry. Roxas, Solano,Nueva Vizcaya. She is married to Mr. Alfredo P. but unfortunately, they are not blessed with a child. Although, they legally adopted a child whom they called Mark Justin P. 7 years old a grade-I pupil. They want their adopted child to be successful in the future so that he will be the one to take care of them when they got old. In this regard, they are doing all their best to support his education so that he will find a stable job someday. 
	Farming is the common source of their living, they till their land twice a year by planting rice and some vegetables. Since harvesting takes a long time, Mrs. Evangeline put-up a small sari-sari or general store in their village to earn additional income. She used the loan she availed in the Microfinance organization to acquire different grocery items, soft drinks and frozen foods. Her average income for month is amounting to P 5,000.00 which they utilized to acquire their daily basic needs and to pay her weekly loan amortization. Due to our economic crisis, she wants to strengthen her small business to increase her income to satisfy their basic needs and save for their future. She applied a higher amount of P 5,000.00 to strengthen her capital in improving her small store. She wants to buy more grocery items to be able to increase more profit.

loans.use: additional capital to purchase grocery items in her store

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en: Maricel L. is from the village of Tabo-o, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 28 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Maricel owns and operates a business offering motorcycle transport services. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Maricel joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,500 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase tires and other accessories. Maricel is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase tires and other accessories. This loan will be her third from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family’s general living conditions. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase tires and other accessories

loans.name: Fayiba

texts.en: Fayiba F. is currently in the business of selling maize, sorghum (a type of grain), etc., and is requesting a loan to purchase millet (another type of grain) to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a store for her cereals to protect them from rain and from the maize weevil. Fayiba is 36 years old and is married with a husband who is a secretary. They have five children who all go to school. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy millet to sell

loans.name: El

texts.en:
El L., 36, is married with four school-aged children. She resides in Battambong Province, Cambodia with her husband and children.

L. is engaged in the business of manufacturing hand-made brooms, earning an income of US$2.50 per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of US $2.5 per day. He has to travel from place to place to construction sites in the town.

This couple tries to work hard every day to ensure a good living for their children and family. L. is seeking to improve her business, so she is asking for a loan of US$300 to purchase more materials for making brooms. By doing so, she hopes she will be able to generate more income to keep investing in her business and to save more money for future household use.

loans.use: To buy more materials to produce hand-made brooms

loans.name: Mally

texts.en:
Mally P., 47 years old, is a rice farmer. She has seven children. Her eldest child is 25 and she has been doing her best to be able to buy her family food, clothes and other needs. She has been wishing that her farm has an abundant harvest. In that way, she will be able to better support her family.

She is for asking a loan of Php 10,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to fund her farm and buy the necessary tools to grow her harvest. She will also use the loan to pay the laborers who helped prapare the soil. The loan is very helpful to sustain her livelihood.

loans.use: Farm financing

loans.name: Peang

texts.en: Peang S., 38, is married with two school-aged children. She resides in Battambong Province, Cambodia with her husband and children. To make a living, she is engaged in the agriculture sector of growing few types of mushrooms, earning an income of US $5 per day in revenue. Her husband helps his wife to double her work and earns the same amount of income she does. This couple tries to work hard every day to ensure good living for their children and family. S. is seeking to improve her business, so she is asking for a loan of US $600 to purchase a motorbike that will enable them to transport mushrooms to sell at the markets easily. By doing so, she hopes she will be able to generate more income to keep investing in her business and cut back on public transportation expenses.

loans.use: buy a motorbike to transport mushrooms for sale

loans.name: Noeu

texts.en: Noeu H., age 33, is married to Svay Ran, age 33. She has five single children, most employed as garment workers. She and her husband have been earning a living for many years by planting a rice crop on their own land next to their house. Farming business is very common for poor people who live in the commune. She and her husband have earned a better income since all their children grew up. Noeu H. is looking for a loan to buy a cow because her old cow doesn't support her field work.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Melissa

texts.en:
Melissa L., 35 years old is a rice grower. She also raises pigs to be able to raise income for her family. The income she makes in her farm and piggery helps a lot to pay the daily costs in their home. She has three children. Her eldest is 30 years old and no longer live with them.

She is asking a loan of Php 10,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to fund her farm. Some of the loan as well will be used to buy additional piglets and feeds.

loans.use: Farm financing

loans.name: Kitoy

texts.en:
Kitoy C. is currently in the business of selling sweets, biscuits etc at the shop and is requesting a loan to purchase plates and cups to sell.  Kitoy is 28 years old and is married to a soldier. She has three children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a department store.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase  plates and cups to sell

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica is 28 years of age and she is married to Melchor B., who is a driver, they are blessed with two children namely; Melvin- 8 years old, grade 2 in primary level, and Ma. Monica- 6 years of age, grade 1. They are presently residing at Baranggay San Francisco, Alicia Isabela, a rural and plain area, approximately four kilometers away from the national highway.
She manages a poultry business (cobb-raising) for almost three years, her net income is PHP 2,000.00 when she disposed after 15 days. She plans to avail a loan amount of PHP 4,000.00 for starting capital. She hopes that KIVA lenders will grant her loan immediately. She's been blessed with productive business, because of that she is thankful to those people who support and helped her.

loans.use: Additional capital in her Poultry business

loans.name: Sylvia

texts.en:
Sylvia M. owns a small rice field in their village. Majority of her time, she tills the farm to be able to help her husband earn adequate income to buy food and other basic needs at home. She has three children. Her eldest child is 14 years old only. Now, she is a bit worried where to get money to support the college education of her child.

She wanted to grow the size of her harvest that is why she applied for a loan of Php 9,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farming nnecssities like rice seeds. Some of the loan will be used to pay the laborers who helped during land preparation.

loans.use: Rice seeds

loans.name: Kitoy

texts.en:
Kitoy C. is currently in the business of selling sweet, biscuits etc at the shop and is requesting a loan to purchase plates and cups to sell.  

Kitoy is 28 years old and is Married with a husband that is a soldier. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a departmental stores.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase plates and cups to sell

loans.name: Jhonna

texts.en:
Jhonna G. is 33 years old. She has been operating a junk shop business for almost one year. Her weekly net income is PHP 2,000.00. She wants a loan of PHP 4,000.00 from KIVA lenders for her additional capital to buy junk materials and she hopes to become productive in due time, to support her family in their needs. 

She is married to Renato G., a farmer and they are blessed with three children.  Jonathan is 10 years old and a grade 5 student, followed by Renato Jr. who is 8 years old and in grade 3. Their youngest is John Rey who is 5 years of age. They are residing at Baranggay San Francisco, Isabela. Their house is located near the rice farm and fish ponds. She hopes that her loan will be granted as soon as possible. She believes that "Prayer changes everything, just have faith on Him."

loans.use: Additional capital for her Junk shop

loans.name: Pich

texts.en: Pich B., 26, is single and resides in Battambong Province, Cambodia with his sister (pictured). To make a living, he purchases chickens from local farmers in his province to resell, earning an income of US $5 per day in revenue. His sister is responsible for transporting the chickens to sell at the market, earning an income of US $3.5 per day. They try to work hard every day to ensure a good living for their family. B. is seeking to improve his business, so he is asking for a loan of US $500 to purchase more chickens to expand his business. By doing so, he hopes he will be able to generate more income to keep investing in his business and save more money for future household use.

loans.use: To buy more chickens for resale

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie is 40 years old and already a widow.  Her husband died 14 years ago and she was left with three children.  Her eldest child is Roxanne- 18 years old, 3rd year college; Re-Anne-15 years old, 4th year high school student and the youngest is Rustom- 14 years old , 3rd year high school student. They are presently residing at San Francisco, Alicia, Isabela. Her sources of income are farming, direct selling, and an honorarium salary of PHP1,600.00 from their village.

She operates a village store and she can earn a weekly net income of PHP500-600.00.  She is now asking for financial support from the KIVA lenders amounting to PHP7,000.00 that she can use for her store.  She hopes that the lenders will grant her loan for her to pursue her business plans.

loans.use: Additional Capital in her retail store

loans.name: Suy

texts.en: Mrs. Suy S. is a local chef. She is also hired by people who need her to cook food for their parties. She is 59 and a widowed mother who has given birth to two daughters. One of the daughters is married and one is single. Suy S. also depends on other income from her both daughters who are garment workers for industry at Phnom Penh. Because Suy S. doesn’t have her own motorcycle, she always needs to pay much money for a taxi. To help facilitate transportation, Suy S. requested a loan of US$300 to buy an old motorcycle, which she will use to drive to work.

loans.use: To buy an old motorcycle

loans.name: Marife

texts.en:
Marife B., 35 years old is a rice grower from Sta. Josefa Agusan Del Sur. She has three children who are students. Her eldest child is 14 years old. She has been doing the best she can to help her husband earn an income to buy the family's needs.

She is asking for a loan of Php 9,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to fund her farm by buying the farm necessities. With her loan, she will be able to sustain her livelihood and have adequate food for her family.

loans.use: To buy farm necessities

loans.name: Jemelita

texts.en:
Jemelita O. is a rice grower. She started her business in 2000. Her only child is nine years old.  She has been doing the best she can to help her husband earn an income for their family needs like food, clothes and other basic needs for their home. 

She is requesting a loan of Php 9,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to fund her farm by buying farming necessities. Receiving a loan will definitely help her achieve not just a better yield but income for her family as well.

loans.use: To buy farming necessities

loans.name: Elona

texts.en:
Elona B., 41 years old, is a rice farmer and a pig grower. She has four children that she puts all her attention to. She has been doing the very best way she can to be able to buy her family food, clothes and other basic needs for their home. 

She is requesting a loan of Php 10,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. to be able to fund her farm and buy the necessary tools to grow her harvest. The loan as well will help improve her piggery. The loan will also help her pay the laborers who helped till their farm during land preparation.

loans.use: To buy farming necessities and pig feed

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
As a 50-year-old mother, she aims to improve the standard of living of her family with the help of NWTF-Project Dungganon. By taking advantage of the opportunity given to put up her own business and be involved in process of development,  this mother named Elizabeth D., married to Genciano D. and blessed with four children, is taking the positive steps toward that goal.

The family lives in the village of Sitio Pader, Brgy. Aguisan, Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental. Of the four children, two have already graduated from college and Elizabeth is very hopeful that the younger ones will also be able to finish their college education and be gainfully employed in the next few years.


Because she wanted to help her husband to earn a living and to sustain the needs of her family, she decided to put up a business using the skills she already had. But she was worried about where she could get the necessary capital for her proposed business. In 1997 she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon to borrow the start-up capital for a vegetable vending venture at the local market.  She used the loan to buy the vegetable stock to start her business and added a part of the income to add to her revolving working capital. She noticed that her business did well and it was not long before she was able to afford a permanent stall in the market where her regular customers would be able to find her each time they went to the market. 

As time went on, she was able to borrow bigger loans because she was a good member who paid her installments on time, and she was able to buy more stock to sell. From her buy and sell of vegetables she was able to earn a minimum of Php 5,000 per month. She used part of the income for the education of her children and savings and some portion she used to help with household expenses.

Her previous loan of Php 25,000 was used as working capital for her vegetable vending business. She paid all her weekly installment in full within the loan term and now for her next 19th cycle she is borrowing the same amount of Php 25,000 to be used again as additional capital for her business and the income will go to support the continuing college education of her two younger children.

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: Additional capital for buying and selling vegetables

loans.name: Nelson

texts.en:
Nelson D. owns and manages a small rice field. His farm is what he hopes will provide his family with enough income to buy adequate food, clothes and other basic needs. He has six children and his eldest child is 27 years old now and is already working.

Most of the harvest is saved for the family's own consumption while the remainder is sold to their neighbors for additional income.

Nelson would like to grow his business more. He intends to fund his farm by buying farming necessities to improve his harvest. Receiving a loan is truly worthwhile since he doesn’t have ready cash to finance his business at present.

loans.use: To use for farm financing

loans.name: Maria Lucena

texts.en:
Maria Lucena Q. is from the village of Poblacion, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is 39 years old and married with two grown children. To make a living, Maria Lucena owns and operates a business planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables to sell. Maria Lucena has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $50 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Maria Lucena joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maria Lucena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Maria Lucena is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This will be her fourth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise

loans.name: Bahrom

texts.ru: Бахром Рахимов проживает в районе Турсунзаде. Возраст 48 лет. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Бахром по специальности более 11 лет проработал "мантером". В данный момент он имеет собственный магазин, где более 5 лет занимается торговлей продуктами питания. Кредит просит для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Bahrom R. lives in the Tursun-zoda region. He is 48 years old. He is married and has four children. Bahrom has worked in his profession as a technician for eleven years. At this time he has own store where he has been selling groceries for more than five years. He is asking for a loan to increase commodity circulation.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase commodity circulation

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Chhoem's Group

texts.en: Pictured here are three low-income people who have decided to seek a loan for different purposes. One of these people, Mrs. Chhoem S., 42, has been chosen to be the leader of this loan group by the other members. Chhoem S. is a widow and has three children, one of whom is married while the others are single. One of her daughters works in a garment factory. To earn a living, Chhoem S. plants a rice crop on the land in the village. She needs a loan in order to buy fertilizer to grow a rice crop during the approaching rice season. The other two borrowers are Suos S., a farmer, who is asking for a loan to buy more fertilizer for her business, and Mel Y, a palm climber, who is requesting a loan to build a ladder for climbing palm trees.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to grow a rice crop during the approaching rice season

loans.name: Hakim

texts.ru: Курбонов Хаким проживает в районе Турсунзаде. Возраст 36 лет. Женат, имеет 3 детей. Хаким имеет среднее образование. Он вот как 16 лет занимается торговлей лепешек, которые сам печет в своей хлебопекарни. Ему в этом также помогает его семья. Кредит просит для закупа сырья и увеличения товараоборота.

loans.use: Закуп сырья

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Khja Zakerullah

texts.en:
K. Zakerullah is the son of K. B.. He lives in Kabul, Afghanistan. He lives in a family of six members. His younger brother is engaged and he is going to get married.

K. Zakerullah needs money for the expenses of his brother’s wedding. As most people know, Afghan people have different customs and they have to spend a lot of money on weddings, so he has requested an individual loan of 30,000 Afghani. He would like to say that the loan process is the best because it can support those who really need money.

loans.use: his brother's wedding expenses

loans.name: Honorata

texts.en:
Honorata makes a living through her vegetable-vending business. It has been her source of income for many years.  She always aims for business expansion for the welfare of her family.  She purchases her vegetables in the public market, though sometimes she also sells her own harvest from their farm.  Honorata would like to increase her profits by having additional capital to purchase more vegetables. Some of her loan will also be helpful in sustaining the needs of her small farm. She hopes for a loan of PHP11,000 from KIVA lenders.

Honorata is 39 years old and married to Mario, who is busy with their farm in their village located in Minallo, Naguilian, Isabela. They are blessed with four children, three of whom are in high school while the youngest is only four years old.

loans.use: Additional capital to purchase more vegetables

loans.name: Koffi Hyppo

texts.fr: Cet homme habite le quartier d’Anfamé à Lomé ; il n’est pas marié et n’a aucun enfant à sa charge. Pour se prendre en charge, il exerce comme activité génératrice de revenus la vente de matériels électriques à son domicile. Il a appris le métier d’électricité, plus précisément il est monteur électricien. C’est en 2007 qu’il s’est lancé dans la vente de matériels électroniques pour pourvoir aussi gagner une clientèle sur le terrain. A présent il est connu de beaucoup de personnes qui apprécient son travail toujours bien fait et qui sait bien accueillir sa clientèle. Il a un besoin pressant en ce moment de renouveler son stock électrique ; pour cette raison, il sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter des rouleaux de fils électriques et divers autres matériels indispensables.

loans.use: Achat de matériels électriques

loans.name: Ismatullo

texts.ru: Исматулло Примов проживает в районе Турсунзаде. Возраст 41 год. Женат, имеет 2 детей. По специальности Исматулло проработал "электромантером" более 2 лет. Вот более 2 лет занимается торвлей на рынке. Он в основном торгует бакалеей, т.е. рисом, чичевицей, горохом и т.д. Кредит просит для увеличения товараоборота.

loans.use: Увеличение товараоборота

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Dédé Ametoyona

texts.fr: Cette femme s’est mariée à un chauffeur de taxi et le couple a 04 enfants. Les revenus du mari n’arrivent plus entièrement à couvrir tous les besoins scolaires des enfants et du foyer ; c’est pour cette raison que cette dame s’est lancée l’année passée dans la vente des produits d’alimentation générale dans le quartier de Bè – Aveto à Lomé. Elle vend des produits comme des tomates, des sardines, des pâtes alimentaires, des sacs de riz et bien d’autres produits indispensables. Elle a loué une boutique qui est très fréquentée par de nombreux clients à cause du bon accueil qu’elle leur réserve en tout temps. Elle a un besoin pressant en ce moment de renouveler son stock en baisse ; c’est pour cela qu’elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 05 cartons de sphaguetti, 02 cartons d’eau de javel, 03 cartons de sardines, 05 sacs de riz et bien d’autres produits. Elle a l’assurance de rembourser son crédit à temps.
texts.en:
This woman is married to a taxi driver and the couple have 4 children. Her husband's income is not quite sufficient to cover school expenses for the children; that is the reason why this lady began last year to sell foodstuffs in the Bè – Aveto neighborhood in Lomé. She sells such goods as tomatoes, sardines, pasta, sacks of rice, and other indispensable products. She has rented a little store which is visited by numerous customers because of this lady's hearty welcome.

At this time, she has a pressing need to replenish merchandise that is out of stock. That is why she is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy 5 cases of spaghetti, 2 cases of bleach, 3 cases of sardines, 5 sacks of rice, and many other products. She feels certain that she will be able to reimburse her loan in a timely manner.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchasing merchandise for resale

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
Susana D. C. is from the village of Hasaan Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental. She is 49 years old and is married. To make a living, Susana owns and operates a "sari-sari" (variety) store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products, such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste, in the local community. Susana has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately $62 a month for these activities.

In 2007, Susana joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Susana has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. Susana is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her fifth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by her store toward improving the business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Kunggeibai

texts.en:
Kunggeibai T. is 40 years old and lives with his wife and his 7-year-old daughter in Bayan-Olgii province, one of Mongolia's western provinces. His daughter is a 2nd grader in a local high school. Kunggeibai has a small shop that offers welding service for locals. He has been in the welding business since 2005 and his business has been the main source of his family income since then. With his business profits, he has been able to finance building a small house in a small plot of land that his family owns. As there is no company that offers various welding related services in his town, he is usually busy with local customers’ orders. His short-term goal is to finish building his house with his business profits. He further says that he would like to open a savings account for his daughter. 
He requests a loan to purchase raw materials for his welding business.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials for his welding business

loans.name: Altanhuyag

texts.en:
Altanhuyag S. is 42 years old and currently lives with his wife and two children in Zavhan province, one of Mongolia's western provinces. His 20-year-old daughter is a 10th grade student in a local high school and his son is an 8th grader in the local school. Altanhuyag sells various dairy products, including cheese, curds, milk, cream, etc. He visits herder families in the countryside, purchases various dairy products at a lower price, and sells them in a small dairy shop that he runs in Uliastai sum, the capital center of Zavhan province. Altanhuyag dreams of having his own farm with livestock one day and opening a shop for his own dairy products. He requests a loan to purchase more dairy products from herder families for his business.

Altanhuyag's wife, who helps him run the dairy shop, is pictured above.

loans.use: To purchase more dairy products from herder families for his business

loans.name: Marites

texts.en: Marites A. is from the town of Northern Pob. Calamba Mis.Occ.. She is 40 years old. Marites is married and has 1 school-aged children. To make a living, Marites is starting a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Marites is just starting this business.In 2009, Marites joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marites is requesting a new loan of 3000 PHP which will be used to purchase breeding livestock. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Marites from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family.  Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: Capital for her  proposed  project

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty L. is from the village of Panay Daku Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 52 years old and married with four grown children. To make a living, Betty owns and operates a business planting and harvesting coconuts to sell. Betty has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately $225 a month for these activities.

In 2004, Betty joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Betty has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from GDMPC. Betty is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This will be her seventh loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her sales to expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business.

loans.name: Elma

texts.en:
Elma G. is from the village of Guinabot, Sapang Dalaga. She is 40 years old and married with one school-age child. To make a living, Elma makes and sells snacks and other delicacies in the local community. She is just starting this business. In 2008, she joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from PMPC. She is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her second loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her sales to expand her business.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: Additional Capital for her business

loans.name: Chenita

texts.en:
Chenita Q. previously lived in Zamboanga del Sur on the island of Mindanao together with her family, but the family decided to move back to Negros Occidental in 1991. Before they left Zamboanga del Sur, they sold their property so that they could have enough capital to start a new life in Negros. When they arrived in Negros, they used the money to buy land and planted fruit-bearing trees like calamansi, guava, and pineapple.

Today Chenita is 49 years old and lives in the village of Sitio Minahan, Brgy. Odiong, Moises Padilla, Negros Occidenal. She is married to Abuncio who takes care of their farm. The couple is blessed with three children who are 12 to 20 years of age, and are all still going to school. Her older son plans to join the military in Bulacan when he graduates from the Negros State College of Agriculture in Kabankalan City, and this is why Chenita and her husband are working really hard so that they can help their son reach his goals.

Their small farm earned a good income for the family and Chenita started a pig-fattening business to supplement their income from the farm. In 1998, Chenita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon because she needed fresh capital to buy fertilizer and other necessities for the farm and her pig-fattening business. When she paid off her loan, she borrowed new capital and started to sell generic medicine in her community. For all her efforts she earns a $340 monthly income from her various businesses.

Previously, for her 14th cycle loan, she borrowed Php 11,000 to use as capital for her businesses. That loan was fully paid in full and on time without any delays. For her 15th cycle loan she is borrowing Php 20,000 to use as additional working capital for her generic medicine business and to buy fertilizer for their farm.  Whatever additional income results from the loan will be used for the education of her children and for the expansion of the businesses.

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day to surpassing realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: Additional capital for her Generics Medicine business and for farm supplies

loans.name: Hodewa

texts.fr: Cette femme assure seule l’éducation scolaire de ses 02 enfants ; elle a loué un petit entrepôt de vente de maïs dans le quartier de Kagomé à Lomé. Elle a débuté cette activité depuis 2005 et cela lui permet de subvenir à tous les besoins de sa famille. Elle approvisionne presque tout le quartier en sacs de maïs ce qui leur permet de ne pas parcourir de longues distances pour se rendre au Grand Marché de Lomé. Elle vend aussi bien en gros qu’en détail. Elle veut en ce moment disposer de nouveaux stocks ; c’est pour cela qu’elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour commander 15 sacs de maïs. Elle compte sur sa longue expérience pour rembourser le prêt dans les meilleurs délais.

loans.use: Achat de sacs de maïs

loans.name: Narangerel

texts.en:
Narangerel B. lives with her husband and three children in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her eldest daughter goes to a university in Ulaanbaatar and her other two children are both high school students.

Narangerel has a small business in retail clothing. She rents a small stall in a local market and retails various women’s and men’s clothes. She mostly purchases clothes that are made in Mongolia, from the wholesale markets in the city. She now would like to expand her business by adding more variety of clothes to her stall. She would like to import cheap clothes from Ereen, China, a border town from where many cheap Chinese products are imported to Mongolia.

Narangerel requests a loan to purchase more clothes from Ereen, China.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes from Ereen, China

loans.name: Hort

texts.en: Hort C., 57, is a widow with three children and works as a professional decorates handicrafts living at home in the Takeo province. Since 1990, she has been using beads and other materials to make flower on woman clothes to earn a living and is able to make US$3 each day. Decorates dress is a kind of Khmer traditional dress and people wears it during Water Festival, P’chum Ben or Khmer New Year. It takes around 7-10 days to complete each dress and its price is expensive too. Most of the people prefer hand made than machine made. She said she knows how to decorate from her mother and she has started doing this business since she was not married yet. One of her children is a construction worker and two are professional decorates handicrafts as her. Hort C. would like a loan of US$1200 to purchase a motorbike for her son who works as a worker to commute to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita V. is married to a farmer named Carlos V.. She is selling vegetables in different barangays near in their village using their motorcycle. They are blessed with seven children. Five are presently studying and taking their education. According to her, even farming is their source of income, their trying their best and keep on working just to give their children a good education. With their dreams to finish all their children's studies, they do everything that will help them to attain their dreams. Even they are feeling hot under the heat of the sun and feel the coldness during rainy season, they still working in fields to support the general needs of their family. 

When time of harvesting and selling their products in fields, their income is not enough to support their children's expenditures in school. Lolita wanted to borrow the amount of Php 15,000 for additional capital to buy additional vegetables to sell.  Her profit will be a great help to provide all her children expenditures in school for the whole school year.

loans.use: additional capital to buy more vegetables to sell

loans.name: You

texts.en:
You L. is 27 years old and lives with her young child and her husband in Takeo province. Since 2004, she has been working as a garment factory worker and is able to make about US$2 each day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver and he typically makes US$3 each day.

You L. is asking for a loan of US$500 to make a new investment. She would like to purchase rice in bulk to obtain a special discount and resell at the market.

loans.use: To buy rice in bulk

loans.name: Samen Mashgan Group

texts.en: Samen is the group leader of Samen Mashgan group. There are two members in this group. Each of them wants to take out a loan for expanding her business and making it larger. So they have requested a group loan of 24,000 Afghani. Samen wants to take a loan for her husband who has stationery shop. Shelaw wants to take a loan for her husband who has a vegetable and fruit shop. They admire this process of small loans in Afghanistan.

loans.use: For expanding their family's business

loans.name: Dy

texts.en: Dy S., 58, lives in the Takeo province with his wife and three of his children. Dy and his wife make and sell rice noodle to earn a living and is able to make approximately US$6 each day. People in the community always support their rice noodle because the way the cook soup is so good. However, this couple needs to support three school-aged children. Dy would like to take out a loan of US$500 to purchase rice to make noodle and reinvest in his business.

loans.use: To purchase rice to make noodle.

loans.name: Dongor

texts.en: Dongor M. is a 35 year old single mother who lives with her two children in Uvurkhangai province in central Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian housing tent, near her mother's home. M. operates a clothing trading business out of a stall at the local trading center in her town. She sells a variety of clothes that are imported from China. M. started her clothes selling business in 2008 after managing a consumer good trading business since 1997. She is working very hard to increase her earnings with the hope of expanding her business in the near future. Her ultimate dream is to one day have her own clothing store. M. is requesting a 4,000,000 tugrug (~2800 USD) loan to import clothes from China to sell.

loans.use: To import clothes from China to sell

loans.name: Maria Fe

texts.en:
Maria Fe is a resident of Sta. Cruz, San Manuel, Isabela.  She is married to Bonifacio and they are blessed with son named Brandon John, four years old.  Their income is not enough to meet the needs of their family so she decided to engaged in retailing business.  She now operates a general store in their village for additional source of income.  

Maria Fe wanted to improve their way of living for she does not want to experience again borrowing rice from her neighbors for their meal especially during rainy season. The couple keeps in working hard and having faith in God to fulfill their dreams. Her dream is to expand her business to supply what her customers wants in their village and will have additional income too. In this connection, she wanted to borrow the amount of Php 40,000 to be able to purchase more goods to sell in her store.

loans.use: Additional capital to purchase more goods for her store

location.town: Sta. Cruz, San Manuel, Roxas, Isabela

loans.name: Kokoè

texts.fr: Cette dame vend des produits d’alimentation générale dans le quartier de Sossoukopé à Lomé ; elle est mariée et est mère de 03 enfants. Elle a débuté cette activité depuis 1994 et ce commerce lui permet d’apporter sa contribution financière dans l’éducation scolaire de ses enfants. Elle s’approvisionne le plus souvent au Grand Marché de Lomé et vend de l’eau minérale, du vin, des boissons alcoolisées, des tomates, des pâtes alimentaires, des savons et bien d’autres produits. Elle approvisionne presque tout son voisinage en produits de première nécessité ; elle aime bien son activité et réserve de très bon accueil à sa clientèle. Elle souhaite en ce moment renouveler son stock en baisse ; c’est pour cette raison qu’elle voudrait avoir  un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 03 boîtes de pâtes dentifrices, 05 cartons d’eau minérale, des bouteilles de boissons alcoolisées et des savons de différents types.

loans.use: Achat des produits d'alimentation générale

loans.name: Sarbai

texts.en: Sarbai M. is 48 years old and lives with his wife and five children in Bayan-Ulgii province in western Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. His oldest two children are University students, and the youngest two attend a local secondary school. M. owns and operates a clothing store at his town's local market. He sells a variety of clothes imported from China and Kazakstan. M. started his business in 2003 after working for 3 years selling animal skins. He has had much success in his new trade and has used his earnings to build a store and hire two salespersons. Today, his working capital exceeds 5,000,000 tugrugs (~3500 USD).  For the future, M. hopes to continue to grow his business and says, "All I want is to be able to buy a car after all of my children graduate." He is requesting a 4,000,000 tugrug (~2800 USD) loan to import more clothes from China to sell in his store.

loans.use: To import more clothes from China to sell in his store

loans.name: Sein

texts.en:
Sein S., 26, is married and lives with her husband in Takeo province. She and her husband are traditional singers who typically make US$5 each day. Both of them have been performing in the arts sector since they were young.

Sein S. is asking for loan of US$1200 to make a new investment. Her husband needs to operate a moto-taxi (passenger-carrying motorcycle) to help improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To buy a moto-taxi for her husband

loans.name: Ahènlimbavi

texts.fr: Cette femme est mariée et est mère de 02 enfants ; elle vend des produits d’alimentation générale plus précisément des oignons, de la mayonnaise, du milo, des spaghuettis, des sardines. Grâce à cette activité, elle apporte sa contribution financière dans le foyer. Elle exerce ce commerce depuis 1999 dans le Grand Marché de Lomé. Elle compte dans l’avenir agrandir son petit commerce en louant une boutique dans le marché. Pour le moment, elle vend à la devanture d’une boutique, sous un parasol. Elle a tout de même de très grandes ambitions pour l’avenir ; c’est pour cette raison qu’elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter non seulement certains de ces produits manquants, mais aussi agrandir son commerce.
texts.en:
This woman is married and the mother of 2 children. She sells foodstuffs, more precisely onions, mayonnaise, Milo (a cocoa drink), spaghetti, and sardines. Thanks to this business, she is able to make a financial contribution toward supporting the household. She has been in this business since 1999 in the Big Market of Lomé.

She intends in future to enlarge her little business by renting a store in the market. For the moment, she sells in front of a store, under a parasol. She nevertheless has great ambition for the future; this is why she has asked WAGES for a loan to buy not only some of the products she is lacking, but also to enlarge her business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of foodstuffs for resale

loans.name: Gonchigsuren

texts.en: Gonchigsuren G. is a 43 year old single mother who lives with her father and two children in Khar-khorin, the capital city of the ancient Mongolian empire. Her father is retired, and her two sons are both high school students. She lives with her family in a ger, a traditional Mongolian housing tent. G. currently operates a meat trading business. She purchases meat and other animal products in bulk from herders in the countryside and transports it to Ulaanbaatar, the largest city and capital of Mongolia, where she sells it. G. started her meat trading business in 1995 by selling out of a rented stall at the market in her town. She operated there for 10 years before suffering a major injury that kept her from work for two years. In 2008, using the knowledge, experience and good supplier relationships she had built before her injury, she began transporting meat to UB. G. is requesting a 1,600,000 tugrug (~1120 USD) loan to purchase more meat and meat products for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more meat and meat products for her business

loans.name: San

texts.en:
San T., 49, is a farmer and lives with her husband in Takeo province. She is able to make less than US$1 every day. Her husband is a palm climber. He usually collect palm juice and refines it to palm sugar. He typically makes US$2 every day. This couple has four children: three are in school and one is employed in a private company.

San T. would like to take out a loan of US$600 to purchase a motorbike her son needs to commute to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her son to use to commute to work

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en: Marilou W. lives in the village of Barangay Ayungon, La Carlota City, Negros Occidental. She is 67 years old and single. Even as she is getting on in years, Marilou is still working and doing business to earn a living to support herself and her nephew who is her dependent. She also works hard so that she will have enough savings to support herself and stay independent in her old age. To prepare for her future and to have a stable source of income, Marilou put up a general store adjacent to her house. She sells different kinds of household products for the mothers, and goodies such as candies for the children of the neighborhood. In 2000 Marilou joined NWTF-Project Dungganon to help her business expand. From that loan she was able to buy additional products for her general store and was able to put up a new food-vending business. Her good performance and dedication to improve her business was rewarded by her increasing income capacity which, in turn, allows her to borrow bigger loans to sustain her business expansion. When she was able to borrow a bigger amount, Marilou started raising pigs in her backyard to supplement her income and to have more savings for her future. Her combined business income is PHP 4,000 per month and it helps her support her household and send her nephew to school. For her 13th loan she was able to obtain PHP 16,000 and it was used as working capital. Her loan was repaid on time and in full without any delays in any of the weekly installments. For her next, 14th, loan she is borrowing the same amount of PHP 16,000, again as additional capital for her businesses. The income from this her increased business will be used for her household needs and for the renovation of her store. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the call of not just a few, but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her businesses

loans.name: Darjaa

texts.en:
G. is 53 years old and lives with her husband and two sons in the Hovd province of western Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her two sons, aged 20 and 22, both attend school at the local university and her husband is a driver for a construction company.

G. operates a business in her town making clothes. She not only sews the traditional Mongolian-style clothing, but she also sews European-style clothing.

G. started her own business after retiring from a dressmaking company. Because she has gained a lot of experience, she knows what her customers want and how much they are willing to pay for her quality clothing. She wants to one day upgrade her old sewing machine into a newer, more sophisticated one so that she can experiment with more elaborate designs.

G. is requesting a 550,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase more fabrics and finishing materials for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more fabrics and finishing materials for her business

loans.name: Akoua

texts.fr: Cette dame s’est lancée en 2002 dans le commerce des produits d’alimentation générale dans sa boutique, située dans le quartier d’Ahligo à Lomé. Elle est mariée à un mécanicien chauffeur et le couple a 03 enfants ; cette activité permet à cette dame d’aider financièrement son mari dans l’éducation scolaire de leurs enfants. Actuellement son étalage est presque vide ; c’est pourquoi elle  sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour disposer de nouveaux stocks. Ce prêt lui permettra d’acheter 05 cartons d’eau minérale, 12 cartons de macaroni, 10 cartons de lait Nestlè, 08 cartons de tomates en boîtes, des cartons de savons de toilettes et 10 cartons d’eau de javel. Elle n’a aucune inquiétude pour rembourser son prêt dans les délais qui seront exigés.

loans.use: Achat des produits d'alimentation générale

loans.name: Jantsandorj

texts.en:
B. is 34 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Kharkhorin, the ancient capital of the Mongolian empire. He and his family live together in a "ger," a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. B.’s wife stays home with their youngest child, and the eldest attends a local secondary school.

B., with the help of his youngest brother, operates a car repair business in his town. He began his business in 1998 and has since then been successful enough to buy a microbus and garage. He has also been able to purchase some land nearby where he hopes to begin farming soon.

B. is requesting a 600,000 tugrug (about $420) loan in order to purchase some repair parts and tools. These will help him decrease his repair time and increase his sales.

loans.use: To purchase repair parts and tools in order to decrease his repair time and increase his sales

loans.name: Prak

texts.en:
Prak N., 53, is a widow and lives with two of her children in Takeo province. To earn a living, she has been selling traditional medicines and is able to make US$4 of profit ever day. She is also supported by one of her children who work as a construction worker and typically makes US$3 per day.

Prak N. is asking for a loan of US$1000 to purchase more medicines to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Zaitnai
