texts.en: B. is 40 years old and lives with her husband and four children in the Bayan-Ulgii province of western Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. All four of her children attend a local secondary school and her husband drives a taxi. B. operates a needlework business where she sews many different household products such as wall hangings, cushions, bags, etc. B. graduated from college in 1986 as a seamstress and worked in a public company until it was later privatized. It was then that she and her friend decided to become business partners and after several years of partnership she started her own business in 2000. Since B. has started her own business she has been able to buy her husband a car with which he began his taxi business. She has also been able to hire two assistants for her needlework business. She says, “My goal is to hire more people so that I can help them improve their own lives.” B. is requesting a 1,400,000 tugrug (~980 USD) loan in order to import needlework materials from nearby Kazakhstan.

loans.use: To import needlework materials from nearby Kazakhstan

loans.name: Latifa Shabrghni Group

texts.en: Latifa is the group leader of Latifa Shabrghni group. There are three members in this group and each of them wants to take out a loan for their business, to make it larger. So they have requested a group loan of 30,000 Afghani. Latifa wants to take a loan for the business of tailoring. Zaki wants to take a loan for her husband who is a taxi driver. Bibi Sheren wants to take a loan for her husband who has a bicycle-making shop. They are very happy with this process of small loans in Afghanistan.

loans.use: For business progress

loans.name: Pov

texts.en:
Pov C. is 34 years old and resides with his wife in Takeo province. He is a moto-taxi (passenger-carrying motorcycle and trailer) driver who is able to make US$13 in revenue each day. His wife is a farmer who grows rice and vegetables to earn a living. She typically makes less than US$1 per day. This couple has three young children.

Pov C. is asking for a loan of US$500 to purchase a motorbike and a trailer to run a moto-taxi.

loans.use: To buy a moto-taxi

loans.name: Phuong

texts.en: Phuong T., 48, is a professional decorates handicrafts living at home in the Takeo province. Since 1990, she has been using beads and other materials to make flower on woman clothes to earn a living and is able to make US$3 each day. Decorates dress is a kind of Khmer traditional dress and people wears it during Water Festival, P’chum Ben or Khmer New Year. It takes around 7-10 days to complete each dress and its price is expensive too. Most of the people prefer hand made than machine made. She said she knows how to decorate from her mother and she has started doing this business since she was not married yet. Phuong T. would like a loan of US$800 to purchase beads, silk and materials to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase beads and silk.

loans.name: Heang

texts.en: Heang M. is 43 years old and resides in the Takeo province with her husband and five of her children. She and her husband sell palm fruit to earn a living and are able to make US$5 of profit every day. This couple also supported by three of the children who are garment factories workers. Two of the children are in school. Heang M. would like to a loan of US$800 to make a new investment. She will take this loan to purchase a food stand at tourist resort.

loans.use: To purchase a food stand.

loans.name: Pok

texts.en:
Pok S., 30, sells yams and corn with her husband in the local market of the province of Takeo. They typically make about $6 each day. This couple has four young children: three of them are in school.

Pok S. is asking for a loan of $800 to purchase a motorcycle. She needs this to transport yams and corn to sell at the market.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle to transport her goods to market

loans.name: Suzette

texts.en:
Suzette S. lives in the village of Brgy. Ayungon, La Carlota City, Negros Occidental. She is 52 and has two adult children, ages 26 and 28. Her older son graduated from college with a degree in Mass Communication and already has his own family. Her younger son is a trained radio technician. He has not yet found work in his field of study, so he currently earns his living by driving one of two tricycles (a motorcycle with a sidecar for passengers) owned by Suzette.

Despite being separated from her husband, Suzette strives hard to meet her familial obligations, trying to be both mother and father to her sons. Without the additional support of another breadwinner in the family, Suzette has been doing her utmost to continue pursuing her dreams for her children, because she truly believes that her dream will come true. She holds on and trusts that she can succeed through hard work, perseverance, and full faith in the Almighty.

Her progress out of poverty started in 2003 when she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon and borrowed PHP 3,000 to start a food vending business. She started out as a sort of one-man band: she both cooked the food and sold it to people in her neighborhood. She began buying bananas in bulk and selling them to her neighbors in retail. Her business activities also helped her adjust to her new single status, and she became more independent and empowered because she knew she had the capacity to provide for her young family.

As her business continued to improve, she was able to buy a motorized water pump for her house, which in turn allowed her to raise pigs in her backyard without offending her neighbors with the usual foul odor that occurs when a pig-raising business is not maintained well. From her subsequent loans, she was able to buy tricycles for her sons to drive, allowing them to help earn a living for their families. She was also able to buy the rights to a piece of land. Her combined net income from all her business activities eventually amounted to PHP 3,500 per month.

Because of her good credit performance in her group, her center, and NWTF-PD (Negro Women for Tomorrow Foundation - Project Dungannon), she was able to secure the amount of Php 19,500 for her thirteenth cycle loan, which she used for her business. The loan was paid in timely weekly installments and was fully paid within its set term.

For her fourteenth cycle, she is borrowing Php 25,000 to be used for her business, as well as to pay for motorcycle maintenance, because when the machines are in good condition they are able to generate more income. The profits earned from this loan will be used for the needs of her family.

Suzette is shown in the picture posing with the two tricycles that are in need of maintenance work.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, the Negro Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day to surpassing realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To be used for motorcycle maintenance

loans.name: Renchin-Osor

texts.en: Renchin-Osor O. is 39 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Uvurkhangai province in central Mongolia. She and her family live together in a small house. Her youngest two daughters currently attend a local secondary school. O. operates a flour and rice selling business out of a shipping container at the local market. She travels to Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, two to four times a month to purchase her products and transports them back to her container to sell. O. started her business in 2003 by first renting the container that she now owns. Over the years she has worked hard to build a stable business operation and has gained much experience. Her business is very important to her and her family. She says, "My only wish is to provide a good education for my children and to help them become good people." O. is requesting a 2,500,000 tugrug (~1750 USD) loan to purchase more flour and rice to sell in her business.

loans.use: To purchase more flour and rice to sell in her business

loans.name: Fely

texts.en: A loving and hardworking mother who continuously works for the betterment of her family: this is Fely V.. She is 45 years old and married to Jun V. who is a tricycle driver and who also helps his wife to run their business. They have two children who are 19 and 21 years old and are still studying. The family lives in the village of Barangay Mabini, Cadiz City, Negros Occidental. The couple strives really hard to provide for the future of their children. Jun drives the tricycle (a motorcycle with a passenger sidecar) that they own to shuttle passengers around town for a fee. Fely started a general store using recycled lumber for its structure just so she could have a place to setup her business. She knew even then that, once the business became stable, she would be able to start repairs and improve the structure. In addition to these two businesses, the couple also wakes up before dawn to buy fish either in the market or in the fishing port and sells it in front of their general store. Fely also started selling coffee and snacks as well as coconut wine adjacent to her house. In 2002, Fely joined NWTF-Project Dungganon to access additional capital for their expanding businesses. With more capital, she was able to increase her monthly income to PHP 20,000 on the average, providing their family with a more comfortable living and enabling her to make improvements to her store and house and have some left for savings. Fely borrowed PHP 29,500 on her previous loan which she used as additional capital in her general store business. She paid all of her weekly installments in full without any delays within her loan term. She now is borrowing the same amount of PHP 29,500 to use as working capital for her business. The income from it will be used to support the family's household needs. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the call of not just a few, but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her general store

loans.name: Jesus Love Group

texts.en:
Jesus Love is a group of 5 borrowers which is led by Jennes S. K.. Jennes is a 53-year-old married woman with 2 children. Her children are 23 and 24 years old, and they both studied through the 12th grade. In addition, Jennes cares for a sibling. Due to a lack of financial support from her parents, she had to drop out of college. Jennes and her family live in Molton Corner Brewer Ville on the outskirts of the capital of Liberia, Monrovia.

Jennes is engaged in the business of selling general goods. In particular, she buys general goods such as detergents, candles, matches, and batteries at wholesale prices, and she then sells the goods at retail prices to residents of her village. She has been running this business for 21 years, and she hopes to establish a larger store in the future. She notes that poor road conditions often make it difficult for her to transport new goods to Molton Corner. Regardless, she has a great relationship with her customers, which effectively encourages them to continue buying goods from her business.

She is requesting this loan so that she can purchase additional goods. Her dream is to build a house for her and her family and to thereby improve her family's standard of living.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional goods.

loans.name: Rawzi Hatiq Group

texts.en: Rawzi Hatiq is a two-member group and M. Hatiq is the leader. They want to take a loan for progressing their business and making it larger. So they have requested a group loan of 15,000 Afghani. M. Hatiq wants to take a loan for his general store. Hanifa wants to take a loan for her tailoring business. They thank  AFS and Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For business progress

loans.name: Mykola

texts.en:
Mykola is married. He runs a small business selling women’s clothing in Belaya Tserkov. He owns two vending kiosks in the central market of his home town. Mykola has been in this trade for 10 years. Presently, he has 23,000 Grivnyas. His average gross income is about 20,000 Grivnyas a month. Monthly net profit amounts to 3,730 Grivnyas. 

Mykola is seeking a loan of 10,000 Grivnyas. He is planning to use the loan to purchase additional merchandise for retail sale in his kiosks. Mykola is hoping to continue running his business ensuring sustainability for him and his family. Mykola has good credit history with all his previous loans being paid back promptly.

loans.use: to increase his working capital

loans.name: Amalia

texts.en:
Amalia B., who lives in Cadiz City, Negros Occidental, in the Philippines, is 50 years old and is married with six children. Her husband works as a timekeeper in Hacienda, which earns him a low monthly salary that barely supports the needs of their family. Although some of her children are already adults and can fend for themselves, she has younger children (the youngest being just 9 years old) who still depend on her for all their needs. Amalia's ambition in life is to be able to send her children to school and to help her husband support their family.

For this reason, she decided to set up a general store. Fortunately, she had the foresight to build it in an area where there is a steady flow of pedestrian traffic -- right in front of the tricycle terminal. As time went on, her business steadily improved. Moreover, she used her business skills to continuously improve and enlarge her product lines, such as by stocking up on fast-selling products for a high inventory turnover rate.

In 2005, when she realized that she needed fresh capital in order to take her store to the next level, she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon. By doing so, she was able to borrow much-needed capital to continue her business expansion. And, as she has continued to pay back and borrow new loans, she is happy that her membership with NWTF-PD hsa allowed her to sustain her business momentum. In fact, her business now earns her a net profit of PHP 3,000, which puts her that much closer to meeting her family's dreams.

In her previous loan, she borrowed PHP 7,500 for her 7th cycle loan, which she used as working capital for her general store. Notably, she paid her weekly installment payment in full and in a timely manner, without any delays. For her 8th cycle she is seeking to borrow PHP 15,000 to be used (again) as additional capital. More specifically, she hopes to maximize her income potential with this loan, especially now that the sugar milling season has started once again, thereby opening a new opportunity to sell more goods to the community. She intends to use the income generated from her business to support her family's needs.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 per day to achieving success beyond their wildest imaginations. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable women. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To expand and improve her store by purchasing additional inventory

loans.name: Sergyi

texts.en:
Sergyi is married with two children. He is a small entrepreneur from Mukachevo, Western Ukraine. Sergyi sells women’s lingerie and handbags in one of the local stores in his home town. He started this business 2 years ago. Currently, Sergyi has 43,000 Grivnyas of gross income each month. 

Sergyi seeks to increase assorted merchandise he offers for sale in his store. He is requesting a loan of 7,500 Grivnyas to pursue these plans. Sergyi’s family assists him in his business endeavors. They are very supportive of Sergyi’s plans and believe the current loan will benefit his business promoting its further growth.

loans.use: to increase working capital

loans.name: Vasyl

texts.en:
Vasyl is married. He has two daughters. His family of four lives in a town of Khoost, Western Ukraine. Small towns and villages have little to offer to people in Ukraine. Many have hard time finding a decent paying job and remain unemployed. Vasyl realized he had to find a way to feed his family. This is how he ended up being a small market businessman selling household items in the central marketplace of his home town. Vasyl grew his business a lot in the past 7 years due to his scrupulousness and professional accounting skills. Currently, he has 5,000 Grivnyas of income each month.

Vasyl is requesting a loan of 8,000 Grivnyas to increase his turnover capital and diversify his inventory. He realizes retail household items are always in demand which is why they always sell well. Vasyl is hoping to open additional vending location if his business continues to expand at the same pace.

loans.use: to increase turnover capital

loans.name: Sergyi

texts.en:
Sergyi is married with a toddler son Vladislav. He is a businessman from Drogobych where he sells men’s outer wear and footwear in one of the local markets. Sergyi launched his small vending trade 4 years ago. Ever since his enterprise has grown up to 12,000 Grivnyas in gross income. 

Sergyi is seeking a 9,000 Grivnya loan to re-stock his merchandise for fall and winter season. He is hoping to invest generated income in purchase of one more vending location expanding his business as a result.

loans.use: to invest in stock

loans.name: Juanita

texts.en:
Juanita D. C. is a 55-year-old woman living in Silang, Cavite. She has four grown-up children. She owns and manages a plant nursery, where she takes care of and sells ornamental and flowering plants. The income from her business -- she earns approximately P2,500 per month -- has provided for her family for the last fifteen years.

In 2005, she joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) credit cooperative, which has provided her with much-needed assistance to help her business succeed. She explains that she has just finished repaying her previous loan with the cooperative, and has applied for a new loan in the amount of P10,000 ($225). With the new loan proceeds, she would like to buy more plant seedlings, organic fertilizers, and plant pots. She hopes to set up another nursery in the public market soon, and she dreams of traveling to other countries someday.

About CCT: The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This mission is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical missions in a uniquely Filipino context. The organization serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines in the pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase nursery supplies, including plant seedlings, fertilizers, and plant pots

loans.name: Joselito

texts.en: This is Joselito P., a 42 year old businessman from Pooc II, Silang, Cavite. He is married to Adarna, 38, a factory worker. Two of their four children are in school: one in college, the other in pre-school. Joselito has operated a general store for eight years and, over the years, his business has grown steadily. Recently, he ventured into a scrap-buying business. Along with managing his general store, he buys all kinds of used metal scraps, used bottles, cartons, and old newspapers and sells them to bigger buyers who in turn sell them to bigger recycling plants and foundries. Joselito earns close to P15,000 a month from these business activities. Joselito is now on his 10th loan with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative. He became a member in 2006. He has applied for a new loan of P15,000 to buy more items to sell at his store. In the future, Joselito wants to see his general store be bigger than what it is now, so he can help employ some of his neighbors. He is also saving a lot from his earnings to support his children’s education. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell at his store

loans.name: Bangelyn

texts.en:
This is Bangelyn D. L., age 24, from Tala, Caloocan City. She is married to Raegan, 25, a driver by profession.

Five years ago, Bangelyn started her general store with just a few items to sell and a few thousand pesos in investments. Now she is earning around P 6,000.00 a month. She uses her profits to build up inventories for her store.

Bangelyn is now on her third loan cycle with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative. She has applied for a new loan in the amount of P 8,000.00, with which she will buy more items to sell at her store.

In the future, she wants to see her general store in the future grow significantly so that she can help employ some of her neighbors.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase more items to sell at her store

loans.name: Zone Vay Group

texts.en:
Zone Vay Group is a group of five borrowers led by Bill T. who is 27 years old and a 12th grade student. He is single and does not have a child. He lives in Molton Corner, a community that is situated north of the outskirts of Monrovia, the capital of Liberia.

Bill's business is selling palm oil. He buys palm oil wholesale from farmers and sells retail to residents of Molton Corner. He has been running this business for three years and hopes to become an importer of different kinds of goods in the future.

Bill sometimes faces rainy season problems because it slows down oil production. He talks to his customers with a good manner and provides a good product to customers in order to encourage them to continue buying from him.

Bill needs this loan in order to purchase more palm oil to improve his business. He dreams of buying land and starting to build a house for his family to come.

loans.use: To buy more palm oil

loans.name: Mengmahmat

texts.en:
B. Mengmahmat, age 49, is married with five children. Mengmahmat is a farmer. He tells us that he comes from a farming family and that he does very well financially because he takes good care of his land. Thanks to his savings, he has been able to arrange for the marriage of his elder son. His wife is his biggest supporter. She helps him in anything she can and takes good care of him and the house.

With this loan, Mengmahmat would like to expand his irrigation system, which is fundamental when it comes to farming. The loan will greatly improve Mengmahmat’s income and his family's living standards.

Mengmahmat and his family appreciate your support in helping him improve his business.

More about Tajikistan

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road and being the location of the end of the rule of Alexander the Great. It is also known for its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi, and many others. The country, filled with epic mountain passes, is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, and boasts a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture, and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 percent of the country is mountainous and only 7 percent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

More about IMON International

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchasing seed, mineral fertilizer, fuels, and lubricants.

loans.name: Odera Douglas

texts.en: Douglas is married to Hadijah and they have no children yet. Douglas has been in the business of selling men’s clothing for two years. His business is situated near a university, so his clients are mainly students and other residents within the area. Douglas was introduced to KADET through existing clients and he has no previous credit history. His loan will be used to purchase additional stock: trousers and shirts. With the extra profits, Douglas intends to open a butchery to diversify his work. Douglas believes he is hardworking and hopes to own a boutique. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Jamolidin

texts.en:
M. Jamolidin is 36 years old, married, and has two children. He grows vegetables and sells them in the market for income. He has been working in this kind of business sphere for almost 13 years and gained much experiences. Jamolidin has a large family considering that he is leaving with his parents. With his large family, Jamolidin works almost everyday to generate revenues for to support his family's living. Because of his family relying on vegetable growing, Jamolidin needs a loan to purchase necessary supplies for his current harvest and with that way to earn enough money for supporting his family. This will be his first loan with IMON International and Kiva and his evaluation shows he is qualified to receive the loan.

loans.use: Purchasing seed and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Leonard Nyamongo

texts.en:
Leonard is married to Jackline and they have no children yet.

Leonard operates three businesses: a clinic, beauty shop and rental houses. He has been in the business for two years. He joined KADET through a marketing promotion and has no previous credit history. Leonard intends to use his loan to buy a motorbike for a taxi business so as to further diversiy his businesses.

The Clients' area of business is in a slum, it has a vast population. With the extra profit, the client shall buy more motorbikes. Hopes and dreams of the client are to own motor vehicles for taxi and car hire as the client believes he is focused and hardworking.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Client intends to buy a motorbike for a taxi business so as to diversify his businesses.

loans.name: Khudoyor

texts.en:
S. Khudoyor was born in 1966 in Kumsangir district, where he now works as a farmer. He is married and has 4 children. His main business is agriculture, which provides him with the means to meet the needs of his family. Khudoyor owns a large piece of land where he cultivates different kinds of vegetables but due to the poor quality of the soil and the insects, he is no longer able to satisfy market demand. Very hard-working, he is asking for a loan of $2000 USD to buy seed, mineral fertilizer, fuels and lubricants . The loan will greatly improve Khudoyor’s income and his family's living standards. Khudoyor expresses his gratitude to everyone for supporting him and promises to repay the loan in time.

loans.use: Purchasing seed, mineral fertilizer, fuels and lubricants

loans.name: Life Group

texts.en:
Life Group is a group of five borrowers led by Harrison L.. He is 42 years old and married with three children aged 15 to 19 years old with educational levels of 4th through 11th grade. He and his family live in Molton Corner, north of the outskirts of Monrovia, the capital of Liberia. He works in the Molton Corner Market.

Harrison is a high school graduate but he could not continue to university due to poverty. Instead, he decided to go into business: the sale of pharmaceutical drugs. He buys the drugs wholesale and sells retail in the Molton Corner Market. He has been running this business for fourteen years and started with a small amount of funds generated from friends and family.

Harrison sometimes faces difficulty from customers who buy on credit from him because they hardly ever pay back. That can break a business down but he usually recovers because he sells good drugs to customers. He talks to his customers with a good manner so as to retain them.

Harrison needs this loan in order to purchase more drugs and earn more profit. He plans to establish a bigger pharmacy in the future and dreams of becoming successful and building a house for himself and his family.

loans.use: To buy more pharmaceutical drugs

loans.name: Shakarmo

texts.en:
S. Shakarmo is a very hardworking and independent woman. She has three kids, two of whom she still supports and who are in elementary and high school, respectively. In search of a way to support her household, she started selling groceries 17 years ago. A true entrepreneur, she studies the market to determine client needs and preferences. Industrious and enterprising, Shakarmo is focused on expanding her business. At the same time with the help of her children Shakarmo raises cattle. In order to grow her business, Shakarmo is requesting a loan of 6400 Somoni ($1475 USD), which she will use to purchase foodstuff to be able to offer a wider selection to her customers and increase her income. With the part of the loan she will also buy young cattle. With the increased sales and profits, Shakarmo hopes to expand her grocery and improve the living standards of her family. The well being of Shakarmo’s family and her business are in your hands. Shakarmo and her children are sincerely grateful for your support.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Foodstuff for selling for increasing of the range of goods

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en: Patrick has been selling secondhand clothes in Naivasha town for the last three years. He is 29 years old, is married to Nancy Wanjiru, and they have a new born child who is two weeks old. Patrick was introduced to KADET by his friend who is also a client. Patrick repaid his first loan, which he used to add stock at his business, very well. This will be his second loan, and he plans to buy more clothes to sell. Patrick plans to buy his own piece of land in future where he will make his own home. Businesswise, he wants to divert to a transport business which is very profitable in the area as it serves as a market centre for farmers. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy more secondhand clothes to sell

loans.name: Paul

texts.en: Paul has been a mechanic in Naivasha town for two years now. He is 25 years old and still single. Paul was introduced to KADET by his friend. This will be his first loan and he is planning to buy more tools for his garage. Paul’s future dream is to buy a piece of land and build houses for rent in Naivasha, a fast-growing town. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy more tools for his garage

loans.name: Barbara's Group

texts.en: B. Barbara is the leader of her lending group in Kayunga. She is a hard working and determined lady with a bar business that she has been running for over 10 years in the same location. She started so small with the limited capital that she secured from her husband and friend until she joined her lending group years back to secure loans and these have helped her so much in boosting her business. her bar operates mostly in the evenings when most of her customers are done with their day’s chores until the wee hours of the night. She admits that some of her customers are unruly after consuming a few bottles but due to the experience she has in the business, she knows what to do when such a scenario occurs. Barbara works so hard to ensure that her children can access the best of education to the last level by paying their school fees with much ease. She needs a loan to help recapitalize her business by stocking more crates of sodas, beers and wines since buying in bulk reduces the costs.

loans.use: Restocking her bar with more crates of sodas, beers and wines.

loans.name: Peter Ndungu

texts.en:
Peter is married to Faith and they have three children, Samuel, Elizabeth and Irene.

The client has been in the herbal clinic business for three years and he was introduced to KADET by an existing client group. He has no previous credit history. The loan that Peter wants will be used to increase his stock of food supplements which are in high demand.

Peter's area of business is densely populated with middle level residents; he relies on the sick who have been advised by the doctors to depend on specified food supplements. With the extra profit the client intends to open another shop at an already identified business location.

The client hopes to become a reliable supplier of food supplement and he describes himself focused and determined.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: The loan will be used to increase Peter's stock of food suppliments which are in high demand.

loans.name: Benard

texts.en:
Benard has been operating his retail shop in Naivasha town for the last four years.  He is 26 years old, married to Grace Murendi and has a 3 year old girl.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend who is also a client.  This will be his second loan, and he plans to buy more household goods to sell.  He paid his first loan off very well.

In the future he not only dreams of growing his retail shop, but also of buying his own vehicle which he will use as a taxi to diversify his source of income.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Buy more household goods to sell in his retail shop

loans.name: Keji

texts.en: Keji R. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes and is requesting a loan to purchase more tomatoes and cooking oil to sell. Keji is 20 years old and is married to a clerk. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more tomatoes and cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Celerina

texts.en:
Celerina P. is 7 years older than her husband, Benedicto P., who is now 50 years old. Their children are: Marisol, age 15 and Mary Joy, age 13, both still studying; Elmer, age 32, now married; Melvin, age 30, also married; and Mary Ann, age 22, still single.

Celerina’s husband has been working continuously as a security guard in Taytay Rizal for fifteen years now and this was the one source of their income. But, because they have more expenses in their house plus the expenses of two children in school, Celerina had to think of another way to augment her husband’s insufficient salary.

The solution that Celerina thought of is to start a business that fits their place to produce an extra income. But one of her dilemmas in starting the business was a lack of capital for it. Kiva field partner Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) is the one who solved her dilemma.

Celerina joined ASHI in 2004 and the loan that she received from the institution was used as capital to start the business that she thought of, which is food preparation. Now she wants to again use a loan to improve her business. She wants to buy some necessary things needed in her business like a different bowl where the menu is placed. She also wants to diversify her menu for a much bigger income.

Celerina does everything to make her business grow more. She exerts more effort with the help of her daughter, Mary Ann. Celerina is the one who will buy the ingredients in the afternoon and cook them the next morning and Mary Ann will sell the food. Celerina really does everything to make her business grow in order for her children, and also her grandchildren, to experience a better life.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her food preparation business

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en: Faustina A. sells fresh fish at Elmina. Faustina has received senior high education. She is married and has two children. Her husband is a fisherman. Faustina has been selling fresh fish since 2004. She supports her husband in the payment of school fees and settlement of utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more of her fresh fish to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save up and to build her own house.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy more of her fresh fish to sell.

loans.name: Josephine's Group

texts.en: B. Josephine is 48 years old and married with 6 children as she takes care of other siblings. Josephine is a hard working lady and a nurse operating a pharmacy in Kayunga for 12 years. When she had just joined her lending group, her business was still so low but with the help of loans, she has been able to boost it and now she has a lot of variety in what she sells. She helps contribute to the payment of her children’s school fees and in future, she would like to own more land that will be used for agriculture hence more income. At the moment, Josephine needs a loan to be able to buy more medicines for an increased stock.

loans.use: Buying more medicines for more stock in her drug shop.

loans.name: Veronicah

texts.en:
Veronicah used to run a salon in Naivasha town and due to her other commitments, she had to stop her salon operations.  She now wants to revive the business again and that is why she is applying for this loan from KADET.  Her neighbor, who is also a client, introduced her to KADET.

She is 36 years old, married to Michael Ndungu and has 4 school-age children. 

She is planning to revive the salon and make it be as profitable as it once was.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To revive her salon business

loans.name: Joice

texts.en:
Joice G. is currently in the business of selling tea and bread. She is requesting a loan to purchase more bags of sugar for tea. Joice is 40 years old and is married to a policeman. She has 4 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house to rent out.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of sugar.

loans.name: Good Luck Group

texts.en:
Goog Luck is a group of 5 borrowers led by Prince T.. Prince is 26 years old, a single father of a 3-year-old child in the kindergarten 2 level. 

He is an 11th grade student who depends on business to cater for he and his child.

Peter and his child lives in Molton Corner, north of the outskirts of the capital city, Monrovia, Liberia.

Pater’s business is his center. He owns a call center where he does pay calls, sells mobile phones recharge call cards, and exchange of foreign currencies like United States Dollars and Cefa to residents of Molton Corner.

Peter has been running his business for 2 years and hoping to establish a big foreign exchange bureau in down town Monrovia, Liberia.
He sometimes faces low recharge call card problems that make business bad for him.
Peter needs this loan in order to add up and buy more recharge call card to improve business.
He dreams of giving his child a better education and to prepare him for the future to come.

loans.use: Peter needs this loan in order to add up and buy more recharge call card to improve business.

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita is a proud mother of her 6 children: Michael, aged 38, is now working abroad; Manulito, aged 37, now drives their own tricycle, a type of cab in the Philippines that has 3 wheels; Joseph, aged 35, now works as accounting staff; Verlita, aged 33, now works as teacher in their town; Jessie, aged 27, now works as a consultant in a company; and Bernandita, aged 22, is now studying 3rd year college. Lolita is proud because all of her children have finished their studies, except for Bernandita who is now currently studying. All of them are now married, except Jessie. Of course she is also proud of herself because she really works hard for success and, with the help of her husband who is now 61 years old, 3 years older than her. He has been working as a Baranggay Official in their town for 4 years now. His salary is one of their sources of income. Aside from the salary of her husband, the revenue of the tricycle that her son drives aids also to support them.

When Lolita joined Kiva field partner Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) she used the loan to buy rice for her buying and selling of rice business. Following the success of that business, she invested in the charcoal business. This is Lolita’s 9th cycle loan. She will use the funds to support both of these businesses. She will buy sacks of rice and supplies for the charcoal business. The charcoal business has been affected by typhoon “Ondoy”. If Lolita makes her own charcoal, she will increase her income.

Lolita’s dream now is to make her business grow so that they can build a much bigger and better house. Also, she dreams for her youngest child to finish her studies so that she can help herself and her family improve their life.

loans.use: To finance her rice and charcoal businesses.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary T. is married and has one child. She has a junior high educational background. Mary sells towels and bed sheets at Elmina, near Bantuma, which she has been doing since 1998. Her husband is a security personnel. Mary uses her income to support the husband in the payment of school fees and settlement of utility bills. Mary will use the loan to purchase towels and bed sheets in bulk. With the new profits from her expanded business, Mary plans to save enough money to build her own house.

loans.use: Mary will use the loan to purchase bails of towel and bed sheets.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John has been repairing bicycles in Naivasha town for the past year.  Naivasha is a rural town, so bicycles are a popular means of transport. Hence, John saw the market for bicycle repairs. He is 31 years old, married to Eunice Njambi and has 2 school-age children. John was introduced to KADET by a friend who is also a client of KADET. This will be his first loan and he is planning to stock his stand with spare parts for bicycle repair. In the near future, he hopes to move into a shop and to stop working from the roadside.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy spare parts for his bicycle repair business.

loans.name: Hanifa's Group

texts.en: N. Hanifa is the leader of her lending group in Kayunga. She is a very hard working lady and a mother of 6 children as she takes care of her other siblings. Hanifa is a business lady that sells smoked fish to families and restaurants in and around her village. She buys the fresh fish from the landing sites in Mukono and smokes the fish herself which enables her to save more. For the experience she has in the business, Hanifa is able to make 200,000/= as profits a week, although she wants for this to increase since the school fees and other family needs keep on demanding. She admires those people that sell her fish hence in future, she would want to join the fishing trade and supply the fish herself hence increasing her income and profits. At the moment, Hanifa needs a loan to be able to buy more fish for smoking hence resale.

loans.use: Buying more fish for smoking and resale.

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en:
Jackline P. is currently in the business of selling phaste and tomatoes  and is requesting a loan to purchase more groundnut and  make phaste to sell.  Jackline is 29 years old and is Married with a husband that is a clinician. She has 4 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a parmanent house for her family.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase more groundnut and make phaste to sell

loans.name: Sophia Achando

texts.en:
Sophia is married to Wycliffe and they have four children: Joyce, Shawyne, Victoria and Blessings.

Sophia has been in the clothing material business for five years. She was introduced to KADET through existing groups and she has no previous credit history. Sophia will use the loan to increase the stock of materials as the demand is higher than she can currently accomodate with existing materials.

The client's area of business is within an estate occupied by middle level residents, her customers are house occupants in the estate. With the extra profits  Sophia plans to purchase a sewing machine.

Sophia's hopes are to own a clothing material shop as she believes she is hardworking and focused.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: The loan will be used to increase the stock of materials for Sophia's clothing material business

loans.name: Helen Nyanga

texts.en:
Helen has been in the grocery business for fourteen years. Her other source of income is from rental houses. She was introduced to KADET through group members. The area of her business is located in an estate with food as the main source of business. Occupants of the rental houses and the neighboring neighbors are her customers. Helen is single with no children

The loan will be used to increase Helen's stock of vegetables and to renovate rental houses. With the extra profits, Helen intends to increase the number of the rental houses she has. In future the client hopes to build permanent building for the purpose of rental which will achieve higher profits.

Helen describes herself as focused and hardworking.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: The loan will be used to increase stock of vegetables and renovate rental houses.

loans.name: Umijima

texts.en:
Umijima J. is currently in the business of selling rice, beans, etc. and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of rice to sell.  Umijima is 30 years old and is married to a policeman. She has 4 children and her children all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her family.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. loans.use: To stock more bags of rice to sell.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth has been selling fish and ground nuts for the last year in the town of Naivasha.  She sells the fish and ground nuts from her house. She is 36 years old, married to David Maina and they have 2 school-age and attending children.

She was introduced to KADET by her friend.  This will be her first loan and she plans to buy more fish to sell.  

Her future plans are buy a piece of land where she will build rental houses.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Buy more fish for sell

loans.name: Ajelina

texts.en:
Ajelina J. is currently in the business of selling beer at the bar and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer to sell. Ajelina is 32 years old and is married. Her husband works in security for UN. She has 3 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children. 

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: stock more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: God Love You Group

texts.en:
God love You is a group of 5 borrowers led by Korto B.. Korto is 54 years old  and married. She has 2 children, aged 20 and 32 years old, their educational levels are 11th grade and a university graduate.
Korto is illiterate because she happens to be a victim of the belief that women don't need to be educated because they will be taken care of by their husbands. She and her family lives in the Molton Corner, north of the outskirts of the capital of Monrovia, Liberia.

Korto's business is selling fish. She buys fish wholesale from fishermen and sells retail to residents to of Molton Corner, north of the outskirts of the capital city, Monrovia, Liberia. She has been running this business for 15 years and hopes to start selling wholesale to retailers. Korto talks to her customers in a good manner and sells fresh fish to customers in order to encourage them to continue buying from her but she sometimes faces supply shortages, which is not good for business.
She needs this loan in order to purchase more fish to serve to her customers. Korto dreams of improving the living standard of her family and to educate her children.

loans.use: She needs this loan in order to purchase more fish to serve to her customers.

loans.name: Walid

texts.en: Walid is a 27-year-old married man. He has owned a car repair shop since 2000 and has 15 years of experience in this field when he started in this domain when he was too young to be able to improve his living situation. Today, Walid is requesting to borrow $500 to purchase a specified machine to develop his work.

loans.use: purchase a specified machine

loans.name: Jamila

texts.en:
Jamila is 37 years old and married to an accountant. She has 4 children: Mulhat, 16 years old; Sumeya-,13 years old; Khalid,10 years old and Imran, 7 years old. 

Jamila owns a salon and also sells beauty products. She has been doing this for 15 years. She also supplies clothes to boutiques. With the loan she has requested from KADET, she will use 20,000 KSH to purchase hair treatment chemicals, 20,000 KSH for a steaming machine and the remaining 40,000 KSH will be used to buy creams for skincare and facials.

Jamila was introduced to KADET by her friends who are existing members of the organization. Previously, she was working with Faulu. 

Jamila's salon is located in a neighborhood in Malindi town and her customers are residents of Malindi. Jamila aims to build her own business premises, with the additional revenue generated from this loan, rather than renting. Jamila's hopes and dreams are to own her own house, buy a car and to establish a successful business.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Purchase products for her business, a salon.

loans.name: Benon's Group

texts.en: Benon M. is 43 years old and is the leader of his group in Bushenyi. He is married with four children whose ages range from 17 years old to 4 years old. Mr. M. has been running a cattle business for six years. His strategy has been to buy undernourished looking cows at low costs and then to feed them hearty diets and provide them with proper care, so that they then may regain full health and be sold at higher prices.  Benon would like to use the loan to buy more medicine for his cattle, so he may further improve their health. He believes that his productivity and hard working nature will give him an edge against competitors and allow him to eventually scale his business so that he may begin selling his cattle in large quantities at local town centers. Benon hopes that his business will continue to expand so that he may better provide for his family.

loans.use: Proper Medicines for Cattle

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther has been in a small retail business in Naivasha town for the last two years. She is 27 years old, married to George Kimani, and has three school-age children. She was introduced to KADET by her friend. This will be her first loan and she plans to use it to add more goods for her store. In the future, she plans to build rental houses on the piece of land that she already owns.

About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients. KADET provides financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is a micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke/.

loans.use: To add more goods to sell in her retail shop

loans.name: Mondong

texts.en:
Mondong M. is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs at a restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of rice and pulses, such as lentils, beans and peas, to sell. Mondong is 30 years old and is married with a husband who is a policeman. She has five children who all go to school. With the extra profit from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a clinic in the nearby market.

About BRAC: BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services. The programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more bags of rice and pulses

loans.name: Bassima

texts.en: Bassima is a very hardworking and enterprising married woman with 2 children. In 2000, she decided to work as a home-base tailor after 18 years of experience to help her husband in the household. Today, Bassima is requesting a loan of $1,200 to buy an additional sewing machine and textiles to satisfy the needs of her customers.

loans.use: buy an additional sewing machine and textiles

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac K. C. is a husband to Caroline Kulei and a father of three Dennis K. (8years Std 1 pupil),Victor K. (6years pre-school Top class),and a Toddler Chelagat K.(2years). 

Isaac is borrowing a loan of Kshs 50,000(660 US$. He has had six previous loans from KADET which he has been able to service and repay well. He intends to use the loan to purchase timber,velvets,modern workshop tools, nails,key and locks. 

Isaac was introduced to KADET LTD by a community leader who happens to be a KADET client. His businness is based in Kabarnet Town(in The Municipal council Jua Kali Shade).Most of Isaac's clients are Kabarnet residents,schools and other institutions.

Isaac intends to open a hardware store in future where he can get materials for his workshop instead of purchasing them from other retailers. His immediate plan is to start planting horticultural crops to be managed by his wife, as this will help to mitigate the current food shortage experience in the district.Isaac's hopes and dreams are to purchase motorbike and later a matatu for public transport business. Isaac is hardworking, creative and ambitious.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Isaac will use this loan to purchase workshop materials and tools.

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul has been a motorbike taxi operator in Naivasha town for over seven years. He also runs a tailoring business on the side. He is 44 years old, married to Lucy Mumbi, and they have four school-age children. Paul was introduced to KADET by his friend. This will be his first loan with the organization and, with this loan, he is planning to buy more clothing material for his tailoring business, which is run by his wife. His future plan is to go into real estate – to buy a piece of land and build rental houses in Naivasha, a fast-growing town.

About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients. KADET provides financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is a micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke/.

loans.use: To buy material for a tailoring business

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en: Hussein is a married man with 6 children. He's 55 years old. He has been working as a farmer since 1990. Over the years, thanks to his business income, he has been able to meet his family needs. After this long experience, Hussein is applying for a loan of $1,000 to purchase more supplies and merchandise in order to increase his business productivity.

loans.use: purchase more supplies and merchandise

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter has been in the motorcycle transport business in Naivasha town for three years now. He is 31 years old, married to Florence Wangari, and they have three school-age children. He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his second loan with KADET. With this loan, Peter plans to start a poultry rearing business and sell eggs and meat in the nearby market. His future dream is to continue in the transport business, upgrading from a motorbike to a taxi, as well as to be active in the poultry business.

About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients. KADET provides financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is a micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke/.

loans.use: To start a poultry rearing business

loans.name: Noel

texts.en:
Noel J. is currently in the business of selling onions and cooking oil and is requesting a loan to purchase fish to sell.  Noel is 30 years old and is Married with a husband that is a nurse. She has 5 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to send her children to school and provide them with school uniforms.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase fish to sell

loans.name: Gerjes

texts.en:
Gerjes is a 46 year old man who lives in Tripoli, northern Lebanon. Gerjes has been selling bread in his car. He sells to grocers stores, to other shops and he also sells in villages. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to do some maintenance work on his car. This is his second cycle and he has always paid on time. 
His previous loan helped him improve his work. Gerjes is special in his work because he knows how to treat his clients; since he sees them a lot, they became friends. His clients are his friends, neighbors and shops. When he first started his business, he didn’t face difficulty excepting the traffic in the street to get from one place to another. Gerjes decided on doing his business because he wanted to improve his income. In the future, he plans on expanding his work by going to other villages in the North.

loans.use: To do some maintenance work on his car.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali has been working as a florist since 1985. He is a 62-year-old man who lives in Tripoli, northern Lebanon. Ali does nice flower arrangements and bouquets. His clients are his friends and neighbors. He didn’t have a lot of flower choices when he first started his business. Ali has always liked flowers and he decided to become a florist.

Ali requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase new flowers. This is his second loan cycle and he has always repaid on time. His previous loan helped him improve his work and purchase more exotic flowers. In the future, he plans on further improving his work.

loans.use: To purchase new flowers.

loans.name: Naji

texts.en: Naji is a 33-year-old engaged man living with his parents. He has owned a barber shop called “Salon Naji" since 2000 to earn income. Thanks to his business income, he has been able to improve his living conditions and, over the years, he has become well known in his town. Today, Naji is requesting to borrow $1,200 to add new decor to his shop in order to attract new clients.

loans.use: To add new decor to his shop

loans.name: Maria Magdalena

texts.es:
Maria  es socia del Bancomunal Avancemos Juntos, es casada, tiene 49 años y dos hijos mayores, pero son solteros y viven con ella.
Maria empezó vendiendo queso por pedidos, pero la necesitad económica aumentaba y empezó a vender ropa, ofreciendo a sus mismos clientes, y tuvo la idea de empezar hacer chocotejas, conoció una chica que le enseño y se puso a vender y le esta yendo bien.   
En finca, gracias a los prestamos que dan esta progresando poco a poco, su capital aumento 
Necesita un préstamo de 2000 soles, para la compra de ropa que le han pedido y compra de insumos para la preparación de chocotejas.
El sueño de Maria es importar sus chocotejas y tener un local donde pueda vender.

loans.use: compra de ropa que le han pedido

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 44-year-old man who lives in Tripoli in northern Lebanon with his wife and their four children. Ali has been working as a furniture maker and repairer since 1987. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase tools for his work and new thread for the furniture. This is his fourth loan cycle and he has always paid on time. 

His previous loan helped him improve his work. Ali is special in his work because he does it well and has experience. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties except in building a network. Ali decided on doing his business because of his experience. In the future, he plans on improving his work.

loans.use: To purchase tools for his work

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
Mohamad is a 26 year old man who lives in Tripoli, northern Lebanon. Mohamad has been working as a car electrician since 2005. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase tools for his work. This is his third cycle and he has always paid on time. 
His previous loan helped him improve his work. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he had some financial issues to purchase the required tools. Mohamad decided on doing his business because of his experience, but the idea came randomly after he had to repair his own car, he saw that he liked the job. In the future, he plans on improving his work.

loans.use: To purchase tools for his work.

loans.name: Bader

texts.en:
Bader is a 28 year old man who lives in Tripoli, northern Lebanon with his wife and their child. Bader has been working as a taxi driver for almost two years. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to do some maintenance work on his car. This is the first time that Bader has requested a loan.
Bader is special in his work because clients feel comfortable being with him. His clients are his friends, neighbors and passer-bys. When he first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. Bader decided on doing his business because he wanted to have an independent work.

loans.use: To do some maintenance work on his car.

loans.name: Tetyana

texts.en: Tatyana is a widow. She lives with her daughter who is disabled. Tatyana sells women's clothing at the central market in Kherson city. She has been in this business for 10 years. Tatyana is very disciplined and responsible person. She knows her market sector and buys items that sell well. Tatyana would like to borrow 15,000 UAH to increase the assortment.

loans.use: to increase the assortment

loans.name: Agua De La Vida Group

texts.es: El Banco Comunal denominado  AGUA DE LA VIDA, está conformado por doce señoras que en su mayoría radican en la Zona San Luis, una de las zonas humildes de la ciudad; la característica principal de sus casas, es que son de adobe en gran parte de ellas son inquilinas o en anticrético. La directiva está conformada por la Sra. Celestina, Sra. Maxima y la Sra. Simona. Las socias de este grupo se desempeñan en un mercado altamente competitivo en los rubros de confección de mantas y ropa, venta de ropa, venta de comida y condimentos, venta de mantas y venta de carne. Pero debido a su grado de experiencia en los diferentes rubros saben cómo salir adelante. Ellas necesitan el crédito para realizar compras de materia prima tales como telas, hilos y lanas; ellas están muy animadas por trabajar con Agrocapital y de forma verbal ellas solicitaron el crédito. Este grupo está emprendiendo su segundo ciclo, la mayoría de ellas se conocen entre sí, es un grupo de personas muy alegres. Se hace notar que en la foto se encuentran dos varones que son los esposos de Delmira y Simona quienes no pudieron ir a la primera reunión, ellos salen en la foto en representación de ellas.

loans.use: INCREMENTO DE CAPITAL DE TRABAJO

loans.name: Jovia's Group

texts.en:
Jovia T. originally started her business brewing beer for the local population. Her success in this enterprise allowed her to raise enough capital to buy two goats. For the past four years, Jovia has exclusively dealt in the goat trade. She is 57 years old and the leader of her group in Bushenyi. She is married with five children who are all currently enrolled in school.

Jovia would like to use this loan to purchase more goats and increase her stock. Her eventual business goal is to, one day, shift into the cattle trade, which is more capital intensive but has the potential for higher profits. Endowed with great determination, Jovia is certain that her business will continue to grow and she hopes to be able to support the education of her children.

loans.use: To purchase more goats

loans.name: Nazih

texts.en:
Nazih is a 55 year old man who lives in Tripoli, northern Lebanon with his wife and their four children. Nazih has been selling fruits and vegetables in his van since 1984. His clients are his friends, neighbors and fruits and vegetables shops. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase fruits and vegetables. This is the first time that Nazih has requested a loan.
Nazih is special in his work because all his clients like him and feel comfortable buying from him since he sells a good quality of merchandise. When he first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. Nazih decided on doing his business because he wanted to have an independent work.

loans.use: To purchase fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Nawal

texts.en: Nawal is a married woman with 5 children. She has been working hard, as a tailor, since 1990 to satisfy the heavy demands of her family. Today, Nawal is applying for a loan of $1,000. With her loan she will buy a new sewing machine to expand her business and to develop her work.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 40-year-old man who lives in Tripoli, northern Lebanon with his wife and their two children. Ali has been producing and selling coal since 1996. He also works as a farmer. His clients are his friends, neighbors, coal shops and sometimes he also sells to restaurants and cafes. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase a cow to start producing dairy products. This is the first time that Ali has requested a loan.
Ali is special in his work because he is known for his good work. When he first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. Ali decided on doing his business because he wanted to have independent work.

loans.use: To purchase a cow.

loans.name: Zafer

texts.en: Zafer is a 30-year-old single man. He has owned a small advertising shop in his town since 2002. He works hard to expand his business and improve it. Today, Zafer is requesting to borrow $1,200 to purchase more merchandise and a machine for his business to earn more income.

loans.use: to purchase more merchandise and a machine.

loans.name: Thanks You Allah Group

texts.en:
Thank You Allah is a group of 5 borrowers led by Hawa S., 37 years old. Hawa is married with 2 children, aged 16 in 9th grade and 18 years old, a high school graduate. She is illiterate herself, due to poverty.
She and her family live in Molton Corner but she works in Dualla Market, the biggest food market north of the capital, Monrovia,Liberia .

Hawa's business is selling food from rural Liberia. She buys food like cassava beans, oil and plantain from farmers and she sells retail in the Dualla market, north of the capital, Monrovia,Liberia. She has been running this business for 11 years. Hawa hopes to grow her business to the level where she can have a shop and sell general goods, in the future.
Hawa talks to her customers in a good manner and offers them good prices in order to encourage them to continue buying from her. She needs this loan in order to purchase more goods like Cassava oil, farina and etc.
Hawaa dreams of improving the standard of living for her family by educating her children and building a house for the family.

loans.use: She needs this loan in order to purchase more goods to sell.

loans.name: Mina Chojlla Group

texts.es:
Mina Chojlla es un grupo de 15 señoras alegres y dinámicas, que se reúnen cada catorce días, en el Centro Focal Los Andes, actualmente están juntas aproximadamente tres años.
Valeriana Añaya, casada y madre de 3 niños, es una de las integrantes y cuenta que está en el grupo hace 1 año y ½, ingresó al grupo por invitación de su sobrina y porque necesitaba capital para  su negocio, ella vende comida, inicialmente trabajaba como cocinera y quiso independizarse hace 2 años. Vende todos los días en un lugar cerca de su domicilio, actualmente necesita del préstamo para comprar capital fijo, es decir, mesas y sillas.
Las demás integrantes también tienen sus propios negocios como el tejido de chompas, producción de zapatos, venta de ropa y alimentos secos, todas necesitan el préstamo para comprar mercadería o materia prima.
texts.en:
Mina Chojlla is a group of 15 happy and dynamic women. They meet every 14 days in the Los Andes Community Center. They have been together for approximately three years. Valeriana Añaya is married and has three children. She is one of the members, and she says she has been in the group for one and a half years. She joined the group because her niece invited her, and she needed capital for her business. She sells food. She first worked as a cook, and two years ago she wanted to be independent. She sells everyday in a place close to her home. She currently needs a loan to buy tables and chairs. The rest of the members also have their own businesses like weaving sweaters, making shoes, and selling clothes and dried food. All of them need the loan to buy merchandise or raw material.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise and raw material

loans.name: Djanati

texts.en: Djanati U. is 32 years old, is married with 3 children ages 10 years, 7 years and 5 years. Djanati has an experience of 6 years selling eggs as a wholeseller. Djanati employs 3 people in her business.  She sells to locals and passersby everyday from 6AM - 630PM. Djanati is requesting her first loan from Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business through purchasing more eggs for her to sell.
